<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_de1132_1_1"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="de1132_part_i."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_de1132_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Part&nbsp;I.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="de1132_item_i._business"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_de1132_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item I. Business    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>General  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Macerich Company (the "Company") is involved in the acquisition, ownership, development, redevelopment, management and leasing of regional and community shopping centers
located throughout the United States. The Company is the sole general partner of, and owns a majority of the ownership interests in, The Macerich Partnership, L.P., a Delaware limited partnership (the
"Operating Partnership"). As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Operating Partnership owned or had an ownership interest in 58 regional shopping centers, 18 community shopping centers and two
development properties aggregating approximately 58&nbsp;million square feet of gross leasable area ("GLA"). These 78 regional, community and development shopping centers are referred to hereinafter
as the "Centers", unless the context otherwise requires. The Company is a self-administered and self-managed real estate investment trust ("REIT") and conducts all of its
operations through the Operating Partnership and the Company's management companies, Macerich Property Management Company, LLC, a single-member Delaware limited liability company, Macerich Management
Company, a California corporation, Westcor Partners, LLC, a single member Arizona limited liability company, Macerich Westcor Management, LLC, a single member Delaware limited liability company and
Westcor Partners of Colorado, LLC, a Colorado limited liability company. The three Westcor management companies are collectively referred to as the "Westcor Management Companies." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company was organized as a Maryland corporation in September&nbsp;1993 to continue and expand the shopping center operations of Mace Siegel, Arthur M. Coppola, Dana K. Anderson and Edward C.
Coppola and certain of their business associates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>All
references to the Company in this Form&nbsp;10-K include the Company, those entities owned or controlled by the Company and predecessors of the Company, unless the context indicates
otherwise. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Developments  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On January&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's 50% interest in FlatIron Crossing. The purchase price consisted of approximately
$68.3&nbsp;million in cash plus the assumption of the joint venture partner's share of debt of $90.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company acquired Northridge Mall, an 864,071 square foot super-regional mall in Salinas, California. The total purchase price was $128.5&nbsp;million and was funded
by sale proceeds from Bristol Center (see "Dispositions") and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;18, 2003, the Company acquired Biltmore Fashion Park, a 610,477 square foot regional mall in Phoenix, Arizona. The total purchase price was $158.5&nbsp;million, which included the
assumption of $77.4&nbsp;million of debt. The Company also issued 705,636 partnership units of the Operating Partnership at a price of $42.80 per unit. The balance of the Company's 50% share of the
purchase price of $10.5&nbsp;million was </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>1</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_de1132_1_2"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>funded
by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. Biltmore Fashion Park is owned in a <SUP>50</SUP>/<SMALL>50</SMALL> partnership with an institutional partner. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;30, 2004, the Company, in a 50/50 joint venture with a private investment company, acquired Inland Center, a 1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in San Bernardino,
California. The total purchase price was $63.3&nbsp;million and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $54&nbsp;million fixed rate loan on the property. The Company's share
of the remainder of the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>B.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing Activitiy  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On May&nbsp;13, 2003, the Company issued $250&nbsp;million in unsecured notes maturing in May&nbsp;2007 with a one-year extension option bearing interest at
LIBOR plus 2.50%. The proceeds were used to pay down and create more availability under the Company's line of credit. In October&nbsp;2003, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement
which will effectively fix the interest rate at 4.45% from November&nbsp;2003 to October&nbsp;13, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
August&nbsp;7, 2003, the Company paid off the loan at Greeley Mall and placed a new $30.0&nbsp;million ten-year fixed rate loan on the property with an interest rate of 6.18%. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
September&nbsp;2003, the Company replaced floating rate loans at Chandler Festival and Chandler Gateway with new five year fixed rate loans of $32.0&nbsp;million and $20.0&nbsp;million,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;4, 2003, the Company closed on a $200&nbsp;million fixed rate ten-year loan on FlatIron Crossing bearing interest at 5.23%. Loan proceeds were used to pay off a
$180&nbsp;million floating rate loan secured by the property. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has reached agreement on an $85.0&nbsp;million, five-year fixed rate loan with an interest rate of 4.63% on Northridge Mall. The rate on the loan is locked and this financing
is expected to close in April&nbsp;2004. Loan proceeds are expected to pay down the Company's unsecured floating rate debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>C.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Redevelopment and Development Activity  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At Queens Center, the redevelopment and expansion continued. The project will increase the size of the center from 622,297 square feet to approximately 1&nbsp;million square
feet. Completion is planned in phases starting in 2004 with stabilization expected in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Lakewood Mall, Target opened a two-level Target store in the location formerly occupied by Montgomery Ward in October&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Redmond Town Center, Bon Marche opened a new department store in July&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Construction
continues at Scottsdale 101, a 420,824 square foot power center in north Phoenix and construction also continues at La Encantada, a 255,325 square foot specialty center in Tucson,
Arizona. Both of these projects are planned to open in phases through 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>2</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=4,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=972187,FOLIO='2',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DE1132A.;16',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:14' -->
<A NAME="page_de1132_1_3"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Somersville Town Center in Antioch, California, a new 106,685 square foot Macy's store is under construction and is expected to open in the fall of 2004. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Nordstrom
announced plans to open a 144,000 square foot store at The Oaks Mall in Thousand Oaks, California. This store opening is planned in conjunction with an expansion of the existing mall
tentatively scheduled to open in 2007. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>D.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dispositions  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On January&nbsp;2, 2003, the Company sold its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway, a 296,153 square foot Phoenix area urban village, for approximately
$29.4&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used to repay a portion of the Company's term loan. The sale resulted in a loss on sale of asset of $0.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company sold 49.9% of its partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera for a total purchase price of approximately $65.9&nbsp;million, which included the
assumption of a proportionate amount of the partnership debt in the amount of approximately $34.7&nbsp;million. The Company is retaining a 50.1% partnership interest and will continue leasing and
managing the asset. The sale resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $8.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;6, 2003, the Shops at Gainey Village, a 138,000 square foot Phoenix area specialty center, was sold for $55.7&nbsp;million. The Company, which owned 50% of this property, received
total proceeds of $15.8&nbsp;million and recorded a gain on sale of asset of $2.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
August&nbsp;4, 2003, the Company sold Bristol Center, a 161,000 square foot community center in Santa Ana, California. The sales price was approximately $30.0&nbsp;million and the Company
recorded a gain on sale of asset of $22.2&nbsp;million which is reflected in discontinued operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>The Shopping Center Industry  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>General  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>There are several types of retail shopping centers, which are differentiated primarily based on size and marketing strategy. Regional shopping centers generally contain in
excess of 400,000 square feet of GLA and are typically anchored by two or more department or large retail stores ("Anchors") and are referred to as "Regional Shopping Centers" or "Malls". Regional
Shopping Centers also typically contain numerous diversified retail stores ("Mall Stores"), most of which are national or regional retailers typically located along corridors connecting the Anchors.
Community Shopping Centers, also referred to as "strip centers" or "urban villages" are retail shopping centers that are designed to attract local or neighborhood customers and are typically anchored
by one or more supermarkets, discount department stores and/or drug stores. Community Shopping Centers typically contain 100,000 square feet to 400,000 square feet of GLA. In addition, freestanding
retail stores are located along the perimeter of the shopping centers ("Freestanding Stores"). Anchors, Mall and Freestanding Stores and other tenants typically contribute funds for the maintenance of
the common areas, property taxes, insurance, advertising and other expenditures related to the operation of the shopping center. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>3</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=5,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=305146,FOLIO='3',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DE1132A.;16',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:14' -->
<A NAME="page_de1132_1_4"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Regional Shopping Centers  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A Regional Shopping Center draws from its trade area by offering a variety of fashion merchandise, hard goods and services and entertainment, often in an enclosed, climate
controlled environment with convenient parking. Regional Shopping Centers provide an array of retail shops and entertainment facilities and often serve as the town center and the preferred gathering
place for community, charity, and promotional events. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Regional
Shopping Centers have generally provided owners with relatively stable growth in income despite the cyclical nature of the retail business. This stability is due both to the diversity of
tenants and to the typical dominance of Regional Shopping Centers in their trade areas. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Regional
Shopping Centers have different strategies with regard to price, merchandise offered and tenant mix, and are generally tailored to meet the needs of their trade areas. Anchor tenants are
located along common areas in a configuration designed to maximize consumer traffic for the benefit of the Mall Stores. Mall GLA, which generally refers to gross leasable area contiguous to the
Anchors for tenants other than Anchors, is leased to a wide variety of smaller retailers. Mall Stores typically account for the majority of the revenues of a Regional Shopping Center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="de1132_business_of_the_company"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_de1132_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Business of the Company    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has a four-pronged business strategy which focuses on the acquisition, leasing and management, redevelopment and development of Regional Shopping
Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company focuses on well-located, quality regional shopping centers that are or can be dominant in their trade
area and have strong capital appreciation potential. The Company subsequently improves operating performance and returns from these properties through leasing, management and redevelopment. Since its
initial public offering ("IPO"), the Company has acquired interests in shopping centers nationwide. The Company believes that it is geographically well positioned to cultivate and maintain ongoing
relationships with potential sellers and financial institutions and to act quickly when acquisition opportunities arise. (See "Recent Developments-Acquisitions"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Leasing and Management  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company believes that the shopping center business requires specialized skills across a broad array of disciplines for effective and profitable operations. For this reason,
the Company has developed a fully integrated real estate organization with in-house acquisition, accounting, development, finance, leasing, legal, marketing, property management and
redevelopment expertise. In addition, the Company emphasizes a philosophy of decentralized property management, leasing and marketing performed by on-site professionals. The Company
believes that this strategy results in the optimal operation, tenant mix and drawing power of each Center as well as the ability to quickly respond to changing competitive conditions of the Center's
trade area. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company believes that on-site property managers can most effectively operate the Centers. Each Center's property manager is responsible for overseeing the operations, marketing,
maintenance and security functions at the Center. Property managers focus special attention on controlling operating costs, a key element in the profitability of the Centers, and seek to develop
strong relationships with and to be responsive to the needs of retailers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>4</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=6,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=67831,FOLIO='4',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DE1132A.;16',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:14' -->
<A NAME="page_de1132_1_5"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Similarly,
the Company generally utilizes on-site and regionally located leasing managers to better understand the market and the community in which a Center is located. Leasing managers are charged
with more than the responsibility of leasing space. The Company continually assesses and fine tunes each Center's tenant mix, identifies and replaces underperforming tenants and seeks to optimize
existing tenant sizes and configurations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
a selective basis, the Company also does property management and leasing for third parties. The Company currently manages three malls for third party owners on a fee basis. In addition, the Company
manages eight community centers for a related party. (See&#151;"Item 13&#151;Certain Relationships and Related Transactions"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Redevelopment.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One of the major components of the Company's growth strategy is its ability to redevelop acquired properties. For this reason,
the Company has built a staff of redevelopment professionals who have primary responsibility for identifying redevelopment opportunities that will result in enhanced long-term financial
returns and market position for the Centers. The redevelopment professionals oversee the design and construction of the projects in addition to obtaining required governmental approvals. (See "Recent
Developments-Redevelopment and Development Activity"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Development.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is pursuing ground-up development projects on a selective basis. The Company believes it can supplement
its strong acquisition, operations and redevelopment skills with its ground-up development expertise to further increase growth opportunities. (See "Recent
Developments&#151;Redevelopment and Development Activity"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Centers.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Centers consist of 58 Regional Shopping Centers, 18 Community Shopping Centers and two
development properties aggregating approximately 58&nbsp;million square feet of GLA. The 58 Regional Shopping Centers in the Company's portfolio average approximately 924,209 square feet of GLA and
range in size from 2.1&nbsp;million square feet of GLA at Lakewood Mall to 328,341 square feet of GLA at Panorama Mall. The Company's 18 Community Shopping Centers have an average of 219,093 square
feet of GLA. The 58 Regional Shopping Centers presently include 241 Anchors totaling approximately 31.3&nbsp;million square feet of GLA and approximately 8,000 Mall and Freestanding Stores totaling
approximately 27.1&nbsp;million square feet of GLA. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Total
revenues, including joint ventures at their pro rata share of $243.2&nbsp;million in 2003 and $212.7&nbsp;million in 2002, increased to $729.2&nbsp;million in 2003 from
$585.2&nbsp;million in 2002 primarily due to the 2002 acquisitions of The Oaks and the Westcor portfolio. See "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations."
No Center generated more than 10% of total shopping center revenues during 2003 and 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cost of Occupancy  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's management believes that in order to maximize the Company's operating cash flow, the Centers' Mall Store tenants must be able to operate profitably. A major factor
contributing to tenant profitability </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>5</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_de1132_1_6"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>is
cost of occupancy. The following table summarizes occupancy costs for Mall Store tenants in the Centers as a percentage of total Mall Store sales for the last three years: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Competition  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>There are numerous owners and developers of real estate that compete with the Company in its trade areas. There are nine other publicly traded mall companies and several large
private mall companies, any of which under certain circumstances could compete against the Company for an acquisition, an Anchor or a tenant. This results in competition for both acquisition of
centers and for tenants or Anchors to occupy space. The existence of competing shopping centers could have a material impact on the Company's ability to lease space and on the level of rent that can
be achieved. There is also increasing competition from other retail formats and technologies, such as lifestyle centers, power centers, internet shopping and home shopping networks, factory outlet
centers, discount shopping clubs and mail-order services that could adversely affect the Company's revenues. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Major Tenants  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Centers derived approximately 93.6% of their total rents for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 from Mall and Freestanding Stores. One tenant accounted for
approximately 4.3% of minimum rents of the Company, and no other single tenant accounted for more than 3.2% as of December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>6</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Includes AT&amp;T Wireless Office headquarters located at Redmond Town Center.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Mall and Freestanding Stores  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Mall and Freestanding Store leases generally provide for tenants to pay rent comprised of a fixed base (or "minimum") rent and a percentage rent based on sales. In some cases,
tenants pay only a fixed minimum rent, and in some cases, tenants pay only percentage rents. Most leases for Mall and Freestanding Stores contain provisions that allow the Centers to recover their
costs for maintenance of the common areas, property taxes, insurance, advertising and other expenditures related to the operations of the Center. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company uses tenant spaces of 10,000 square feet and under for comparing rental rate activity. Tenant space of 10,000 square feet and under in the portfolio at December&nbsp;31, 2003 comprises
61.9% of all Mall and Freestanding Store space. The Company believes that to include space over 10,000 square feet would provide a less meaningful comparison. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>When
an existing lease expires, the Company is often able to enter into a new lease with a higher base rent component. The average base rent for new Mall and Freestanding Store leases, 10,000 square
feet and under, commencing during 2003 was $36.96 per square foot, or 17.1% higher than the average base rent for all Mall and Freestanding Stores (10,000 square feet and under) at December&nbsp;31,
2003 of $31.55 per square foot. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>7</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

expiring during the year.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Bankruptcy and/or Closure of Retail Stores  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A decision by an Anchor or a significant tenant to cease operations at a Center could have an adverse effect on the Company's financial condition. The bankruptcy and/or closure
of an Anchor, or its sale to a less desirable retailer, could adversely affect customer traffic in a Center and thereby reduce the income generated by that Center or otherwise adversely affect the
Company's financial position. Furthermore, the closing of an Anchor could, under certain circumstances, allow certain other Anchors or other tenants to terminate their leases or cease operating their
stores at the Center or otherwise adversely affect occupancy at the Center. In addition, mergers, acquisitions, consolidations or dispositions in the retail industry could result in the loss of
Anchors or tenants at one or more Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Retail
stores at the Centers other than Anchors may also seek the protection of the bankruptcy laws and/or close stores, which could result in the termination of such tenants' leases and thus cause a
reduction in the cash flow generated by the Centers. Although no single retailer accounts for greater than 4.3% of total minimum rents, the bankruptcy and/or closure of stores could result in
decreased occupancy levels, reduced rental income or otherwise adversely impact the Centers. Although certain tenants have filed for bankruptcy, the Company does not believe such filings and any
subsequent closures of their stores will have a material adverse impact on its operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>8</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Includes joint ventures at pro rata share. Currently, 29% of leases have provisions for using an annual multiple of future consumer price index increases which are not reflected in

<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Anchors  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Anchors have traditionally been a major factor in the public's identification with Regional Shopping Centers. Anchors are generally department stores whose merchandise appeals
to a broad range of shoppers. Although the Centers receive a smaller percentage of their operating income from Anchors than from Mall and Freestanding Stores, strong Anchors play an important part in
maintaining customer traffic and making the Centers desirable locations for Mall and Freestanding Store tenants. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Anchors
either own their stores, the land under them and in some cases adjacent parking areas, or enter into long-term leases with an owner at rates that are lower than the rents charged
to tenants of Mall and Freestanding Stores. Each Anchor, which owns its own store, and certain Anchors which lease their stores, enter into reciprocal easement agreements with the owner of the Center
covering among other things, operational matters, initial construction and future expansion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Anchors
accounted for approximately 6.4% of the Company's total rent for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>9</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>10</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=12,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=189296,FOLIO='10',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DG1132A.;12',USER='KSOLTER',CD='12-MAR-2004;03:20' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1132_1_11"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Environmental Matters  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Under various federal, state and local laws, ordinances and regulations, a current or prior owner or operator of real estate may be liable for the costs of removal or
remediation of certain hazardous or toxic substances on, under or in such property. Such laws often impose such liability without regard to whether the owner or operator knew of, or was responsible
for, the presence of such hazardous or toxic substances. The costs of investigation, removal or remediation of such substances may be substantial, and the presence of such substances, or the failure
to properly remediate such substances, may adversely affect the owner's or operator's ability to sell or rent such property or to borrow using such property as collateral. Persons or entities who
arrange for the disposal or treatment of hazardous or toxic substances may also be liable for the costs of removal or remediation of a release of such substances at a disposal or treatment facility,
whether or not such facility is owned or operated by such person or entity. Certain environmental laws impose liability for release of asbestos-containing materials ("ACMs") into the air and third
parties may seek recovery from owners or operators of real properties for personal injury associated with exposure to ACMs.&nbsp;In connection with the ownership (direct or indirect), operation,
management and development of real properties, the Company may be considered an owner or operator of such properties or as having arranged for the disposal or treatment of hazardous or toxic
substances and therefore potentially liable for removal or remediation costs, as well as certain other related costs, including governmental fines and injuries to persons and property. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Each
of the Centers has been subjected to a Phase I audit (which involves review of publicly available information and general property inspections, but does not involve soil sampling or ground water
analysis) completed by an environmental consultant. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Based
on these audits, and on other information, the Company is aware of the following environmental issues that are reasonably possible to result in costs associated with future investigation or
remediation, or in environmental liability: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asbestos</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The Company has conducted ACM surveys at various locations within the Centers. The surveys indicate that
ACMs&nbsp;are present or suspected in certain areas, primarily vinyl floor tiles, mastics, roofing materials, drywall tape and joint compounds. The identified ACMs&nbsp;are generally
non-friable, in good condition, and possess low probabilities for disturbance. At certain Centers where ACMs&nbsp;are present or suspected, however, some ACMs&nbsp;have been or may be
classified as "friable," and ultimately may require removal under certain conditions. The Company has developed and implemented an operations and maintenance (O&amp;M) plan to manage ACMs&nbsp;in place.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Underground Storage Tanks</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Underground storage tanks ("USTs") are or were present at certain of the Centers, often in
connection with tenant operations at gasoline stations or automotive tire, battery and accessory service centers located at such Centers. USTs also may be or have been present at properties
neighboring certain Centers. Some of these tanks have either leaked or are suspected to have leaked. Where leakage has occurred, investigation, remediation, and monitoring costs may be incurred by
the Company if responsible current or former tenants, or other responsible parties, are unavailable to pay such costs. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>11</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=13,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=682940,FOLIO='11',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DG1132A.;12',USER='KSOLTER',CD='12-MAR-2004;03:20' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1132_1_12"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Chlorinated Hydrocarbons</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The presence of chlorinated hydrocarbons such as perchloroethylene ("PCE") and its degradation
byproducts have been detected at certain of the Centers, often in connection with tenant dry cleaning operations. Where PCE has been detected, the Company may incur investigation, remediation and
monitoring costs if responsible current or former tenants, or other responsible parties, are unavailable to pay such costs. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>PCE
has been detected in soil and groundwater in the vicinity of a dry cleaning establishment at North Valley Plaza, formerly owned by a joint venture of which the Company was a 50% member. The
property was sold on December&nbsp;18, 1997. The California Department of Toxic Substances Control ("DTSC") advised the Company in 1995 that very low levels of Dichloroethylene ("1,2 DCE"), a
degradation byproduct of PCE, had been detected in a municipal water well located <SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>4</SMALL> mile west of the dry cleaners, and that the dry cleaning facility may have contributed to the
introduction of 1,2 DCE into the water well. According to DTSC, the maximum contaminant level ("MCL") for 1,2 DCE which is permitted in drinking water is 6 parts per billion ("ppb").
The 1,2 DCE was detected in the water well at a concentration of 1.2 ppb, which is below the MCL. The Company has retained an environmental consultant and has initiated extensive testing of the site.
The joint venture agreed (between itself and the buyer) that it would be responsible for continuing to pursue the investigation and remediation of impacted soil and groundwater resulting from
releases of PCE from the former dry cleaner. A total of $77,803 and $211,092 have already been incurred by the joint venture for remediation, professional and legal fees for the years ending
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively. The joint venture has been sharing costs with former owners of the property. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company acquired Fresno Fashion Fair in December&nbsp;1996. Asbestos was detected in structural fireproofing throughout much of the Center. Testing data conducted by professional environmental
consulting firms indicates that the fireproofing is largely inaccessible to building occupants and is well adhered to the structural members. Additionally, airborne concentrations of asbestos were
well within OSHA's permissible exposure limit ("PEL") of .1 fcc. The accounting at acquisition included a reserve of $3.3&nbsp;million to cover future removal of this asbestos, as
necessary. The Center was recently renovated and a substantial amount of the asbestos was removed. The Company incurred $1,622,269 and $247,478 in remediation costs for the years ending
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively. An additional $0.7&nbsp;million remains reserved at December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Insurance  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Centers have comprehensive liability, fire, flood, terrorism, extended coverage and rental loss insurance. The Company or the joint venture owner, as applicable, also
currently carries earthquake insurance covering the Centers located in California. Such policies are subject to a deductible equal to 5% of the total insured value of each Center, a $100,000 per
occurrence minimum and a combined annual aggregate loss limit of $200&nbsp;million on the Centers located in California. Management believes that such insurance policies have specifications and
insured limits customarily carried for similar properties. See&#151;"Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#151;Uninsured Losses." </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Qualification as a Real Estate Investment Trust  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company elected to be taxed as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the "Code"), commencing with its first taxable year ended December&nbsp;31,
1994, and intends to conduct its </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>12</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=14,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1035792,FOLIO='12',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DG1132A.;12',USER='KSOLTER',CD='12-MAR-2004;03:20' -->
<A NAME="page_dg1132_1_13"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>operations
so as to continue to qualify as a REIT under the Code. As a REIT, the Company generally will not be subject to federal and state income taxes on its net taxable income that it currently
distributes to stockholders. Qualification and taxation as a REIT depends on the Company's ability to meet certain dividend distribution tests, share ownership requirements and various qualification
tests prescribed in the Code. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Employees  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company and the management companies employ 2,175 persons, including eight executive officers, personnel in the areas of acquisitions and
business development (9), property management (762), leasing (100), redevelopment/construction (34), development (21), financial services (135)&nbsp;and legal affairs (55). In addition, in an
effort to minimize operating costs, the Company generally maintains its own security staff (972)&nbsp;and maintenance staff (79). A union represents 13 of these employees. The Company believes that
relations with its employees are good. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Available Information; Website Disclosure; Corporate Governance Documents  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's corporate website address is </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>www.macerich.com</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The Company makes available free of charge through this website its
reports on Forms 10-K, 10-Q and 8-K and all amendments thereto, as soon as reasonably practicable after the reports have been filed with, or furnished to, the
Securities and Exchange Commission. These reports are available under the heading "Investing&#151;SEC Filings," through a free hyperlink to a third-party service. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following documents relating to Corporate Governance are available on the Company's website at </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>www.macerich.com</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> under "Corporate Governance": </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>18</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=20,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=355846,FOLIO='18',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DI1132A.;18',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_di1132_1_19"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> With respect to 66 Centers, the underlying land controlled by the Company is owned in fee entirely by the Company, or, in the case of jointly-owned Centers, by the joint venture
property partnership or limited liability company. With respect to the remaining Centers, the underlying land controlled by the Company is owned by third parties and leased to the Company, the
property partnership or the limited liability company pursuant to long-term ground leases. Under the terms of a typical ground lease, the Company, the property partnership or the limited
liability company pays rent for the use of the land and is generally responsible for all costs and expenses associated with the building and improvements. In some cases, the Company, the property
partnership or the limited liability company has an option or right of first refusal to purchase the land. The termination dates of the ground leases range from 2005 to 2132.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Includes GLA attributable to Anchors (whether owned or non-owned) and Mall and Freestanding Stores as of December&nbsp;31, 2003.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Sales are based on reports by retailers leasing Mall and Freestanding Stores for the twelve months ending December&nbsp;31, 2003 for tenants which have occupied such
stores for a
minimum of 12&nbsp;months. Sales per square foot are based on tenants 10,000 square feet and under, excluding theaters, that occupied their space for the entire year.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Portions of the land on which the Center is situated are subject to one or more ground leases.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On May&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company sold 49.9% of its partnership interest to a joint venture partner.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> These properties have a vacant Anchor location. The Company is contemplating various replacement tenant/redevelopment opportunities for these vacant sites.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On January&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's 50% interest in this Center for approximately $68.3&nbsp;million in cash plus the
assumption of the
Company's joint venture partner's share of debt.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Federated Department Stores is scheduled to open a new 106,685 square foot Macy's store in Fall 2004.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Dillard's at SouthPark is planned for a September&nbsp;2004 opening.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(10)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The office portion of this mixed-use development does not have retail sales.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(11)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Federated Department Stores opened a new 110,000 square foot Bon Marche store at Redmond Town Center in July&nbsp;2003.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(12)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Tenant spaces have been intentionally held off the market and remain vacant because of major development or redevelopment plans. As a result, the Company believes
the percentage of
mall and freestanding GLA leased and the sales per square foot at these major redevelopment properties is not meaningful data.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(13)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Queens Center is currently under expansion. The project will increase the size of the center from 622,297 square feet to approximately 1&nbsp;million square feet.
Completion is
planned in phases starting in 2004 with stabilization expected in 2005. The data provided respresents information concerning the portion of the Center that is not under expansion.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>19</FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Mortgage Debt  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The following table sets forth certain information regarding the mortgages encumbering the Centers, including those Centers in which the Company has less than a 100% interest.
The information set forth below is as of December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Debt
premiums represent the excess of the fair value of debt over the principal value of debt assumed in various acquisitions subsequent to March, 1994 (with interest rates ranging from 3.81% to
7.68%). The debt premiums are being amortized into interest expense over the term of the related debt on a straight-line basis, which approximates the effective interest method. The balances below
include the unamortized premiums as of December&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<TD COLSPAN=16 VALIGN="TOP"><FONT SIZE=1><B>CONSOLIDATED CENTERS:</B></FONT></TD>

<A NAME="page_dk1132_1_22"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Notes:  </I></FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, these properties are being held by the owners as tenants in common and the Company has a direct undivided 50% interest in these
properties.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $1.1&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The annual debt service payment represents the payment of principal and interest. In addition, contingent interest, as defined in the loan agreement, may be due to
the
extent that 35% of the amount by which the property's gross receipts (as defined in the loan agreement) exceeds a base amount specified therein. Contingent interest expense recognized by the Company
was $823,546, $882,311 and $583,751 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note was issued at a discount. The discount was being amortized over the life of the loan using the effective interest method. At December&nbsp;31, 2003 and
2002, the unamortized discount was $231,383 and $264,433, respectively. This loan was paid off in full on February&nbsp;3, 2004.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $0.6&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was entered into on November&nbsp;4, 2003 and the old floating rate loans were paid off in full upon the closing of the transaction.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On August&nbsp;7, 2003, the Company paid off the old loan and placed a new $30.0&nbsp;million ten-year fixed rate loan at an interest rate of 6.18%. The
Company recognized a $0.1&nbsp;million loss on early extinguishment of the old debt.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which may not exceed $51.0&nbsp;million bearing an interest rate at LIBOR plus 2%. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the weighted
average interest rate was 3.18%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This loan was issued on July&nbsp;10, 2001 for $89.0&nbsp;million, and may be increased up to $96.0&nbsp;million subject to certain conditions. In
April&nbsp;2003, the additional $7.0&nbsp;million was funded at a fixed rate of 7.0% until maturity.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(10)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In January&nbsp;2003, the Company placed a $32.2&nbsp;million floating rate note on the property bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.65% and maturing
December&nbsp;31, 2005. The total interest rate at December&nbsp;31, 2003 was 3.22%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(11)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $1.6&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(12)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $2.4&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(13)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which may not exceed $46.3&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.25%. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the total interest
rate was 3.52%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(14)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $0.1&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(15)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $0.1&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(16)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a $225.0&nbsp;million construction loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.50%. The loan converts to a permanent fixed rate loan at 7% subject to
certain conditions including completion and stabilization of the expansion and redevelopment project. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the total interest rate was 3.62%. Northwestern Mutual Life
("NML") is the lender for 50% of the construction loan. The funds advanced by NML are considered related party debt as they are a joint venture partner with the Company in Macerich
Northwestern Associates.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(17)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Concurrent with the acquisition of the mall, the Company placed a $108.0&nbsp;million loan bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15% and maturing July&nbsp;1, 2004 with
three consecutive one year options. $92.0&nbsp;million of the loan is at LIBOR plus 0.7% and $16.0&nbsp;million is at LIBOR plus 3.75%. This variable rate debt is covered by an interest rate  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(25)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $0.9&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(26)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In connection with the acquisition of this property, the joint venture assumed $77.4&nbsp;million of debt at a fixed interest rate of 7.68%. The debt premium of
$11.3&nbsp;million recorded by the joint venture at the date of acquisition represents the excess of the fair value over the principal value of debt. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized
premium, representing the Company's pro rata share, was $5.6&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(27)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $13.3&nbsp;million bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the weighted average
interest rate was 3.14%. Effective January&nbsp;2004, the loan commitment was reduced to $11.4&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(28)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $1.3&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(29)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represented a construction loan which was not to exceed $35.0&nbsp;million and bore interest at LIBOR plus 1.60%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the total
interest rate was 3.04%. On September&nbsp;23, 2003, the joint venture obtained a new $32.0&nbsp;million permanent fixed rate loan of 4.37% maturing in October&nbsp;2008.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(30)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represented a construction loan which was not to exceed $17.0&nbsp;million and bore interest at LIBOR plus 2.0%. At December&nbsp;31, 2002, the total interest
rate was 3.55%. On September&nbsp;25, 2003, the joint venture obtained a new $20.0&nbsp;million permanent fixed rate loan at 5.19% maturing in October&nbsp;2008.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(31)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note was assumed at acquisition. The loan consists of 14 traunches, with a range of maturities from 36&nbsp;months (with two 18-month extension
options) to 60&nbsp;months. The variable rate debt ranges from LIBOR plus 60 basis points to LIBOR plus 250 basis points, and fixed rate debt ranges from 5.01% to 6.18%. An interest rate swap was
entered into to convert $1.5&nbsp;million of floating rate debt with a weighted average interest rate of 3.97% to a fixed rate of 5.39%. The interest rate swap has been designated as a hedge in
accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133. Additionally, interest rate caps were entered into on a portion of the debt and reverse interest rate caps were simultaneously sold to offset the effect of the
interest rate cap agreements. These interest rate caps do not qualify for hedge accounting in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(32)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $0.4&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(33)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In connection with the acquisition of this property, the joint venture assumed $127.0&nbsp;million of collateralized fixed rate notes (the "Notes"). The Notes bear
interest at an average fixed rate of 7.20% and mature in August&nbsp;2005. The Notes require the joint venture to deposit all cash flow from the property operations with a trustee to meet its
obligations under the Notes. Cash in excess of the required amount, as defined, is released. Included in cash and cash equivalents is $750,000 of restricted cash deposited with the trustee at
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and December&nbsp;31, 2002.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<A NAME="page_dk1132_1_24"> </A>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(34)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> On July&nbsp;28, 2000, the joint venture placed a $16.1&nbsp;million floating rate note on the property bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.25% and maturing
July&nbsp;2003. On August&nbsp;24, 2003, the joint venture negotiated a two-year loan extension with the lender and the loan was increased to $17.1&nbsp;million. At
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, the total interest rate was 2.93% and 3.75%, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(35)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $0.2&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(36)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $4.7&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(37)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the unamortized premium was $3.2&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(38)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This represents a construction loan which shall not exceed $54.0&nbsp;million bearing an interest rate at LIBOR plus 2.25%. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the total
interest rate was 3.46%.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(39)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In connection with the acquisition of these Centers, the joint venture assumed $485.0&nbsp;million of mortgage notes payable which are collateralized by the
properties. At acquisition, the $300.0&nbsp;million fixed rate portion of this debt reflected a fair value of $322.7&nbsp;million, which included an unamortized premium of $22.7&nbsp;million.
This premium is being amortized as interest expense over the life of the loan using the effective interest method. At December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, the unamortized balance of the debt premium
was $7.8&nbsp;million and $10.7&nbsp;million, respectively. This debt is due in May&nbsp;2006 and requires monthly payments of $1.9&nbsp;million based on the fixed rate debt in place as of
December&nbsp;31, 2003. $184.5&nbsp;million of this debt was refinanced in May&nbsp;2003 with a new note of $186.5&nbsp;million that requires monthly interest payments at a variable weighted
average rate (based on LIBOR) of 1.57% and 1.92% at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002,
respectively. This variable rate debt is covered by interest rate cap agreements, which effectively prevents the interest rate from exceeding 10.63%.  </I></FONT>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> On April&nbsp;12, 2000, the joint venture issued $138.5&nbsp;million of additional mortgage notes, which are collateralized by the properties and are due in May&nbsp;2006. $57.1&nbsp;million
of this debt requires fixed monthly interest payments of $387,000 at a weighted average rate of 8.13% while the floating rate notes of $81.4&nbsp;million require monthly interest payments at a
variable weighted average rate (based on LIBOR) of 1.53% and 1.79% at December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively. This variable rate debt is covered by an interest rate cap agreement which
effectively prevents the interest rate from exceeding 11.83%.  </I></FONT></P>

</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(40)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> This note was assumed at acquisition. The loan consists of 14 traunches, with a range of maturities from 36&nbsp;months (with two 18-month extension
options) to 60&nbsp;months. The variable rate debt ranges from LIBOR plus 60 basis points to LIBOR plus 250 basis points, and fixed rate debt ranges from 5.01% to 6.18%. An interest rate swap was
entered into to convert $11.4&nbsp;million of floating rate debt with a weighted average interest rate of 3.97% to a fixed rate of 5.39%. The interest rate swap has been designated as a hedge in
accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133. Additionally, interest rate caps were entered into on a portion of the debt and reverse interest rate caps were simultaneously sold to offset the effect of the
interest rate cap agreements. These interest rate caps do not qualify for hedge accounting in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;133.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has a $425.0&nbsp;million revolving line of credit. This revolving line of credit has a three-year term plus a one-year extension. The interest rate fluctuates
from LIBOR plus 1.75% to LIBOR plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. As of December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, $319.0&nbsp;million and $344.0&nbsp;million of borrowings
were outstanding under this credit facility at an average interest rate of 3.69% and 4.72%, respectively. The Company, through its acquisition of Westcor, had an interest rate swap with a
$50.0&nbsp;million notional amount. The swap matured December&nbsp;1, 2003, and was designated as a cash flow hedge. This swap served to reduce exposure to interest rate risk effectively
converting the LIBOR rate on $50.0&nbsp;million of the Company's variable interest rate borrowings to a fixed rate of 3.215%. The swap was reported at fair value, with changes in fair value
recorded as a component of other comprehensive income. Net receipts or payments under the agreement were recorded as an adjustment to interest expense. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=26,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=26482,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DK1132A.;18',USER='SLUSARR',CD='12-MAR-2004;11:13' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1132_1_25"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Concurrent
with the acquisition of Westcor, the Company placed a $380.0&nbsp;million interim loan with a term of six months, plus two six-month extension options bearing interest at an
average rate of LIBOR plus 3.25% and a $250.0&nbsp;million term loan with a maturity of up to three years with two one-year extension options with an interest rate ranging from LIBOR
plus 2.75% to LIBOR plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. On November&nbsp;27, 2002, the entire interim loan was paid off. At December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, $196.8 and
$204.8&nbsp;million of the term loan was outstanding at an interest rate of 3.95% and 4.78%, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;13, 2003, the Company issued $250.0&nbsp;million in unsecured notes maturing in May&nbsp;2007 with a one-year extension option bearing interest at LIBOR plus 2.50%. The
proceeds were used to pay down and create more availability under the Company's line of credit. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the entire $250.0&nbsp;million was outstanding at an interest rate of
4.45%. In October&nbsp;2003, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement which effectively fixed the interest rate at 4.45% from November&nbsp;2003 to October&nbsp;13, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Additionally,
as of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company has contingent obligations of $29.6&nbsp;million in letters of credit guaranteeing performance by the Company of certain obligations
relating to the Centers. The Company does not believe that these letters of credit will result in a liability to the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1132_item_3._legal_proceedings."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1132_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 3. Legal Proceedings.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company, the Operating Partnership, Macerich Management Company, the Westcor Management Companies and their respective affiliates are not currently involved in any material
litigation nor, to the Company's knowledge, is any material litigation currently threatened against such entities or the Centers, other than routine litigation arising in the ordinary course of
business, most of which is expected to be covered by liability insurance. For information about certain environmental matters, see "Business&#151;Environmental Matters." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk1132_item_4._submission_of_m__dk102376"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dk1132_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 4. Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>None. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A

<A NAME="toc_dm1132_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Part&nbsp;II    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1132_item_5._market_for_registrant___ite04647"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1132_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 5. Market for Registrant's Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The common stock of the Company is listed and traded on the New York Stock Exchange ("NYSE") under the symbol "MAC". The common stock began trading on March&nbsp;10, 1994 at a
price of $19 per share. In 2003, the Company's shares traded at a high of $45.16 and a low of $28.65. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>As
of February&nbsp;27, 2004, there were approximately 666 stockholders of record. The following table shows high and low closing prices per share of common stock during each quarter in 2002 and
2003 and dividends/distributions per share of common stock declared and paid by quarter: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company has issued 3,627,131 shares of its Series&nbsp;A cumulative convertible redeemable preferred stock ("Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock"), and 5,487,471 shares of its
Series&nbsp;B cumulative convertible redeemable preferred stock ("Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock"). There is no established public trading market for either the Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock or
the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. The Series&nbsp;A Preferred Stock and Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were issued on February&nbsp;25, 1998 and June&nbsp;16, 1998, respectively. On
September&nbsp;9, 2003, all of the shares of Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were converted to common stock. Preferred stock dividends are accrued quarterly and paid in arrears. The Series&nbsp;A
Preferred Stock can be converted on a one for one basis into common stock and will pay a quarterly dividend equal to the greater of $0.46 per share, or the dividend then payable on a share of common
stock. No dividends will be declared or paid on any class of common or other junior stock </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company's existing financing agreements limit, and any other financing agreements that the Company enters into in the future will likely limit, the Company's ability to pay
cash dividends. Specifically, the Company may pay cash dividends and make other distributions based on a formula derived from Funds from Operations and only if no event of default under the financing
agreements has occurred, unless, under certain circumstances, payment of the distribution is necessary to enable the Company to qualify as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity Compensation Plan Information  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company currently maintains two equity compensation plans for the granting of equity awards to directors, officers and employees: the 2003 Equity Incentive Plan ("2003
Plan") and the Eligible Directors' Deferred Compensation/Phantom Stock Plan ("Director Phantom Stock Plan"). Certain of the Company's outstanding stock awards were granted under other equity
compensation plans which are no longer available for stock awards: the 1994 Eligible Directors' Stock Option Plan (the "Director Plan"), the Amended and Restated 1994 Incentive Plan (the "1994 Plan")
and the 2000 Incentive Plan (the "2000 Plan"). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<TD COLSPAN=7><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Weighted average exercise price of outstanding options; does not include stock units.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Represents 1,038,724 shares subject to outstanding options and 2,000 shares underlying stock units, payable on a one-for-one basis, credited to stock unit
accounts under the 1994 Plan, 88,107 shares underlying stock units, payable on a one-for-one basis, credited to stock unit accounts under the Director Phantom Stock Plan, and
26,500 shares subject to outstanding options under the Director Plan.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Of these shares, 5,955,939 were available for options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock, stock units, stock bonuses, performance based awards, dividend
equivalent rights
and operating partnership units or other convertible or exchangeable units under the 2003 Plan, 161,893 were available for issuance under stock units under the Director Phantom Stock Plan and 750,000
were available for issuance under the Employee Stock Purchase Plan.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I> Represents 20,000 shares subject to outstanding options under the 2000 Plan. The 2000 Plan did not require approval of, and has not been approved by, the Company's
stockholders. No
additional awards will be made under the 2000 Plan. The 2000 Plan generally provided for the grant of options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock awards, stock units, stock bonuses and
dividend equivalent rights to employees, directors and consultants of the Company or its subsidiaries. The only awards that were granted under the 2000&nbsp;Plan were stock options and restricted
stock. The stock options granted generally expire not more than 10&nbsp;years after the date of grant and vest in three equal annual installments, commencing on the first anniversary of the grant
date. The restricted stock grants generally vest over three years.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=30,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1016070,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DM1132A.;35',USER='SLUSARR',CD='12-MAR-2004;11:13' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1132_1_29"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> <A NAME="dm1132_item_6._selected_financial_data."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1132_3"> </A>
<BR>    </I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 6. Selected Financial Data.    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The following sets forth selected financial data for the Company on a historical basis. The following data should be read in conjunction with the financial statements (and the
notes thereto) of the Company and "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations" each included elsewhere in this Form&nbsp;10-K. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Selected Financial Data is presented on a consolidated basis. The limited partnership interests in the Operating Partnership (not owned by the REIT) are reflected as minority interest. Centers and
entities in which the Company does not have a controlling ownership interest (Biltmore Fashion Park, Broadway Plaza, the Village at Corte Madera, Pacific Premier Retail Trust, SDG Macerich Properties,
L.P., West Acres Shopping Center and certain Centers and entities in the Westcor portfolio) are referred to as the "Joint Venture Centers." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Effective
March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Macerich Property Management Company merged with and into Macerich Property Management Company, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Operating Partnership ("MPMC,
LLC") and the Company began consolidating the accounts of MPMC, LLC. Effective July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company began consolidating the accounts of Macerich Management Company, in accordance with
FIN&nbsp;46 (See Note&nbsp;2 of the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements). Prior to March&nbsp;29, 2001 and July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company accounted for Macerich Property Management
Company and Macerich Management Company under the equity method of accounting, respectively. Accordingly, the net income from the Joint Venture Centers and the Macerich Management Companies that is
allocable to the Company is included in the statement of operations as "Equity in income (loss) of unconsolidated joint ventures and management companies." The use of the terms "Macerich Management
Companies" or "management companies" refers to Macerich Property Management Company prior to March&nbsp;29, 2001 and Macerich Management Company prior to July&nbsp;1, 2003 when their accounts were
reflected in the Company's consolidated financial statements under the equity method of accounting. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(1)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> During 2001, the Company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;141, Business Combinations ("SFAS&nbsp;141"). (See "Item 7. Management's Discussion
and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#151;Statement on Critical Accounting Policies"). The amortization of below market leases, which is recorded in minimum rents was
$6.1&nbsp;million and $1.1&nbsp;million for the twelve months ending December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(2)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Unconsolidated joint ventures include all Centers and entities in which the Company does not have a controlling ownership interest and for Macerich Management
Company through
June&nbsp;30, 2003 and for Macerich Property Management Company through March&nbsp;28, 2001. Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Macerich Property Management Company merged with and into MPMC,
LLC. The Company accounts for the joint ventures using the equity method of accounting. Effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Company began consolidating the accounts for MPMC, LLC. Effective
July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company began consolidating the accounts of Macerich Management Company, in accordance with FIN&nbsp;46. (See "Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial
Condition and Results of Operations&#151;New Pronouncements Issued").
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(3)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> "Minority Interest" reflects the ownership interest in the Operating Partnership or other unconsolidated entities not owned by the REIT.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(4)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In December&nbsp;1999, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin 101, "Revenue Recognition in Financial Statements" ("SAB 101"), which
became effective
for periods beginning after December&nbsp;15, 1999. This bulletin modified the timing of revenue recognition for percentage rent received from tenants. This change will defer recognition of a
significant amount of percentage rent for the first three calendar quarters into the fourth quarter. The Company applied this change in accounting principle as of January&nbsp;1, 2000. The
cumulative effect of this change in accounting principle at the adoption date of January&nbsp;1, 2000, including the pro rata share of joint ventures of $0.8&nbsp;million, was approximately
$1.8&nbsp;million. If the Company had recorded percentage rent using the methodology prescribed in SAB 101, the Company's net income available to common stockholders would have been reduced by
$1.3&nbsp;million or $0.02 per diluted share for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 1999.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(5)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> In October&nbsp;2001, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued SFAS&nbsp;144, "Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets"
("SFAS&nbsp;144"). SFAS&nbsp;144 addresses financial accounting and reporting for the impairment or disposal of long-lived assets. This statement supersedes SFAS&nbsp;121,
"Accounting for the Impairment of Long-Lived Assets and for Long-Lived Assets to be Disposed of" ("SFAS&nbsp;121"). SFAS&nbsp;144 establishes a single accounting model,
based on the framework established in SFAS&nbsp;121, for long-lived assets to be disposed of by sale. The Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;144 on January&nbsp;1, 2002. The Company sold
Boulder Plaza on March&nbsp;19, 2002 and in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;144 the results of Boulder Plaza for the periods from January&nbsp;1, 2002 to March&nbsp;19, 2002 and for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001, 2000 and 1999 have been reclassified into "discontinued operations". Total revenues associated with Boulder Plaza was approximately $0.5&nbsp;million for the period
January&nbsp;1, 2002 to March&nbsp;19, 2002 and $2.1&nbsp;million, $2.7&nbsp;million and $2.2&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, 2000 and 1999, respectively.
Additionally, the Company sold its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway on January&nbsp;2, 2003 (acquired in July&nbsp;2002), and the loss on sale of $0.2&nbsp;million has been reclassified
to discontinued operations in 2003. Total revenue associated with Paradise Village Gateway for the period ending December&nbsp;31, 2002 was $2.4&nbsp;million. The Company sold Bristol Center on
August&nbsp;4, 2003, and the results for the period January&nbsp;1, 2003 to August&nbsp;4, 2003 and for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001, 2000 and 1999 have been reclassified to
discontinued operations. The sale of Bristol Center resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $22.2&nbsp;million in 2003. Total revenues associated with Bristol  </I></FONT></DD></DL>
