<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(6)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Earnings per share is based on Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;128 ("SFAS No.&nbsp;128") for all years presented.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(7)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> The Company uses Funds from Operations ("FFO") in addition to net income to report its operating and financial results and considers FFO and FFO-diluted as
supplemental measures for
the real estate industry and a supplement to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ("GAAP") measures. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT") defines FFO as net income
(loss) (computed in accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (or losses) from extraordinary items and sales of depreciated operating properties, plus real estate related depreciation and amortization
and after adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures. Adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures are calculated to reflect FFO on the same basis. FFO and FFO on
a fully diluted basis, are useful to investors in comparing operating and financial results between periods. This is especially true since FFO excludes real estate depreciation and amortization, as
the Company believes real estate values fluctuate based on market conditions rather than depreciating in value ratably on a straight-line basis over time. FFO on a fully diluted basis, is
one of the measures investors find most useful in measuring the dilutive impact of outstanding convertible securities. FFO does not represent cash flow from operations as defined by GAAP, should not
be considered as an alternative to net income as defined by GAAP and is not indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO as presented may not be comparable to similarly titled
measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income see "Item 7, Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial
Condition and Results of Operations-Funds from Operations."  </I></FONT>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> In compliance with the Securities and Exchange Commission's Regulation&nbsp;G and Amended Item 10 of Regulation&nbsp;S-K relating to non-GAAP financial measures, the
Company has revised its FFO definition as of January&nbsp;1, 2003 and for all periods presented, to include gain or loss on sales of peripheral land, impairment of assets, losses on debt-related
transactions and the effect of SFAS No.&nbsp;141 to amortize the below market leases which are recorded in minimum rents. The Company's revised definition is in accordance with the definition
provided by NAREIT.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The inclusion of gains (losses) on sales of peripheral land included in FFO for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002, 2001, 2000 and 1999 were $1.4&nbsp;million (including
$0.4&nbsp;million from joint ventures at pro rata), $2.5&nbsp;million (including $2.4&nbsp;million from joint ventures at pro rata), $0.3&nbsp;million (including $0.1&nbsp;million from joint
ventures at pro rata), ($0.7) million (including ($0.7) million from joint ventures at pro rata), and $1.6&nbsp;million (including $1.6&nbsp;million from joint ventures at pro rata), respectively.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> FFO for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001, 2000 and 1999 have been restated to reflect the Company's share of impairment of assets and losses on debt-related transactions, the
latter of which was previously reported as extraordinary items under GAAP. The Company's write-off of impairment of assets for 2002 was $13.3&nbsp;million (including $10.2&nbsp;million
from joint ventures at pro rata). There were no write-offs of impairment of assets for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, 2000 or 1999. The Company's losses on
debt-related transactions for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001, 2000 and 1999 were $3.6&nbsp;million, $2.0&nbsp;million, $0.5&nbsp;million (including
$0.2&nbsp;million from joint ventures at pro rata) and $1.5&nbsp;million, respectively.  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=1><I> The computation of FFO-diluted includes the effect of outstanding common stock options and restricted stock using the treasury method. The Company had $125.1&nbsp;million of convertible
subordinated debentures (the "Debentures") which matured December&nbsp;15, 2002. The Debentures were dilutive for the twelve month periods ending December&nbsp;31, 2002, 2001, 2000 and 1999 and
were included in the FFO calculation. The Debentures were paid off in full on December&nbsp;13, 2002. On February&nbsp;25, 1998, the Company sold $100&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;A
Preferred Stock. On June&nbsp;16, 1998, the Company sold $150&nbsp;million of its Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock. The preferred stock can be converted on a one-for-one
basis for common stock. The preferred stock was dilutive to FFO in 2003, 2002, 2001, 2000 and 1999 and the preferred stock and the convertible debentures were dilutive to net income in 1999 and the
preferred stock were dilutive to net income in 2003. All of the Series&nbsp;B Preferred Stock were converted to common stock on September&nbsp;9, 2003.  </I></FONT></P>

</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(8)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Assumes that all OP Units and Westcor partnership units are converted to common stock on a one-for-one basis.
<BR><BR> </I></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-9pt;'><FONT SIZE=1><I>(9)</I></FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=1><I> Assumes issuance of common stock for in-the-money options and restricted stock calculated using the Treasury method in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;128 for
all years presented.  </I></FONT></DD></DL>

<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=34,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=764037,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DM1132A.;35',USER='SLUSARR',CD='12-MAR-2004;11:13' -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1132_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1132_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>General Background and Performance Measurement  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company uses Funds from Operations ("FFO") in addition to net income to report its operating and financial results and considers FFO and FFO-diluted, as
supplemental measures for the real estate industry and a supplement to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles ("GAAP") measures. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts ("NAREIT")
defines FFO as net income (loss) (computed in accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (or losses) from extraordinary items and sales of depreciated operating properties, plus real estate related
depreciation and amortization and after adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures. Adjustments for unconsolidated partnerships and joint ventures are calculated to reflect FFO on
the same basis. FFO and FFO on a fully dilutive basis, are useful to investors in comparing operating and financial results between periods. This is especially true since FFO excludes real estate
depreciation and amortization, as the Company believes real estate values fluctuate based on market conditions rather than depreciating in value ratably on a straight-line basis over
time. FFO on a fully diluted basis, is one of the measures investors find most useful in measuring the dilutive impact of outstanding convertible securities. FFO does not represent cash flow from
operations as defined by GAAP, should not be considered as an alternative to net income as defined by GAAP and is not indicative of cash available to fund all cash flow needs. FFO, as presented, may
not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other real estate investment trusts. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income available to common
stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
compliance with the Securities and Exchange Commission's Registration G and Amended Item 10 of Registration S-K relating to non-GAAP financial measures, the Company has revised its FFO definition
as of January 1, 2003 and for all periods presented, to include gain or loss or sales of peripheral land, impairment of assets, losses on debt-related transactions and the effect of SFAS No. 141 to
amortize the
market leases which are recorded in minimum rents. The Company's revised definition is in accordance with the definition provided by NAREIT. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Percentage
rents generally increase or decrease with changes in tenant sales. As leases roll over, however, a portion of historical percentage rent is often converted to minimum rent. It is therefore
common for percentage rents to decrease as minimum rents increase. Accordingly, in discussing financial performance, the Company combines minimum and percentage rents in order to better measure
revenue growth. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
following discussion is based primarily on the consolidated financial statements of the Company for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001. The following discussion compares the
activity for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 to results of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. Also included is a comparison of the activities for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 to the results for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. This information should be read in conjunction with the accompanying consolidated financial statements and notes
thereto. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Forward-Looking Statements  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>This Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K contains or incorporates statements that constitute forward-looking statements. Those statements appear in a number of places
in this Form&nbsp;10-K and include statements regarding, among other matters, the Company's growth, acquisition, redevelopment and development </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=35,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=42796,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DO1132A.;46',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:16' -->
<A NAME="page_do1132_1_34"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>opportunities,
the Company's acquisition and other strategies, regulatory matters pertaining to compliance with governmental regulations and other factors affecting the Company's financial condition
or results of operations. Words such as "expects," "anticipates," "intends," "projects," "predicts," "plans," "believes," "seeks," "estimates," and "should" and variations of these words and similar
expressions, are used in many cases to identify these forward-looking statements. Stockholders are cautioned that any such forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and
involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements of the Company or industry to vary materially from the Company's future results, performance
or achievements, or those of the industry, expressed or implied in such forward-looking statements. Such factors include the matters described herein and the following factors among others: general
industry, economic and business conditions, which will, among other things, affect demand for retail space or retail goods, availability and creditworthiness of current and prospective tenants,
Anchor or tenant bankruptcies, closures, mergers or consolidations, lease rates and terms, availability and cost of financing, interest rate fluctuations and operating expenses; adverse changes in
the real estate markets including, among other things, competition from other companies, retail formats and technologies, risks of real estate redevelopment, development, acquisitions and
dispositions; governmental actions and initiatives (including legislative and regulatory changes); environmental and safety requirements; and terrorist activities that could adversely affect all of
the above factors. The Company will not update any forward-looking information to reflect actual results or changes in the factors affecting the forward-looking information. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Statement on Critical Accounting Policies  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") defines "critical accounting policies" as those that require application of management's most difficult, subjective or complex
judgments, often as a result of the need to make estimates about the effect of matters that are inherently uncertain and may change in subsequent periods. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect
the reported
amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting
period. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Some
of these estimates and assumptions include judgements on revenue recognition, estimates for common area maintenance and real estate tax accruals, provisions for uncollectable accounts, impairment
of long-lived assets, the allocation of purchase price between tangible and intangible assets, and estimates for environmental matters. The Company's significant accounting policies are
described in more detail in Note&nbsp;2 to the Consolidated Financial Statements. However, the following policies could be deemed to be critical within the SEC definition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenue Recognition:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum rental revenues are recognized on a straight-line basis over the terms of the related lease. The difference between the amount of rent due in a year and the
amount recorded as rental income is referred to as the "straight lining of rent adjustment." Currently, 29% of the mall and freestanding leases contain provisions for Consumer Price Index ("CPI")
rent increases periodically throughout the term of the lease. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=36,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=710956,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DO1132A.;46',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:16' -->
<A NAME="page_do1132_1_35"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company believes that using an annual multiple of CPI increases, rather than fixed contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that more closely matches the cash revenue from each
lease and will provide more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. Percentage rents are recognized in accordance with Staff Accounting Bulletin 101. Percentage rents are accrued
when leasees specified sales targets have been met. Recoveries from tenants for real estate taxes, insurance and other shopping center operating expenses are recognized as revenues in the period the
applicable expenses are incurred. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Property:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs related to the development, redevelopment, construction and improvement of properties are capitalized. Interest incurred or imputed on development, redevelopment and
construction projects are capitalized until construction is substantially complete. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Maintenance
and repairs expenses are charged to operations as incurred. Costs for major replacements and betterments, which includes HVAC equipment, roofs, parking lots, etc. are capitalized and
depreciated over their estimated useful lives. Gains and losses are recognized upon disposal or retirement of the related assets and are reflected in earnings, in accordance with SFAS
No.&nbsp;66&#151;"Accounting for Sales of Real Estate." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Property
is recorded at cost and is depreciated using a straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Buildings and improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-40 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant improvements</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>initial term of related lease</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>Equipment and furnishings</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>5-7 years</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=3><HR NOSHADE></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company accounts for all acquisitions entered into subsequent to June&nbsp;30, 2001 in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS")
No.&nbsp;141, Business Combinations ("SFAS&nbsp;141"). The Company will first determine the value of the land and buildings utilizing an "as if vacant" methodology. The Company will then assign a
fair value to any debt assumed at acquisition. The balance of the purchase price will be allocated to tenant improvements and identifiable intangible assets or liabilities. Tenant improvements
represent the tangible assets associated with the existing leases valued on a historical basis prorated over the remaining lease terms. The tenant improvements are classified as an asset under real
estate investments and are depreciated over the remaining lease terms. Identifiable intangible assets and liabiltities relate to the value of in-place operating leases which come in three forms:
(i)&nbsp;origination value, which represents the value associated with "cost avoidance" of acquiring in-place leases, such as lease commissions paid under terms generally experienced in our
markets; (ii)&nbsp;value of in-place leases, which represents the estimated loss of revenue and of costs incurred for the period required to lease the "assumed vacant" property to the occupancy
level when purchased; and (iii)&nbsp;above or below market value of in-place leases, which represents the difference between the contractual rents and market rents at the time of the acquisition,
discounted for tenant credit risks. Origination value is recorded as an other asset and is amortized over the remaining lease terms. Value of in-place leases is recorded as an other asset and
amortized over the remaining lease term plus an estimate of renewal of the acquired leases. Above or below market leases are classified as an other asset or liability, depending on whether the
contractual terms are above or below market, and the asset or liability is amortized to rental revenue over the remaining terms of the leases. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=37,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=332392,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DO1132A.;46',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:16' -->
<A NAME="page_do1132_1_36"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>When
the Company acquires real estate properties, the Company allocates the components of these acquisitions using relative fair values computed using its estimates and assumptions. These estimates
and assumptions impact the amount of costs allocated between various components as well as the amount of costs assigned to individual properties in multiple property acquisitions. These allocations
also impact depreciation expense and gains or loses recorded on future sales of properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depending
on the materiality of the acquisition, the Company may engage a valuation firm to assist with the allocation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;144 on January&nbsp;1, 2002 which addresses financial accounting and reporting for the impairment or disposal of long-lived assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company assesses whether there has been an impairment in the value of its long-lived assets by considering factors such as expected future operating income, trends and prospects, as
well as the effects of demand, competition and other economic factors. Such factors include the tenants' ability to perform their duties and pay rent under the terms of the leases. The Company may
recognize an impairment loss if the cash flows are not sufficient to cover its investment. Such a loss would be determined as the difference between the carrying value and the fair value of a center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Deferred Charges:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Costs relating to obtaining tenant leases are deferred and amortized over the initial term of the agreement using the straight-line method. Cost relating to
financing of shopping center properties are deferred and amortized over the life of the related loan using the straight-line method, which approximates the effective interest method.
In-place lease values are amortized over the remaining lease term plus an estimate of renewal. The present value of leasing commissions and legal costs are amortized on a straight-line basis over the
individual remaining lease years. The range of the terms of the agreements are as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

Ventures and the Management Companies." A pro rata share of the mortgage debt on these properties is shown in Note&nbsp;6 to the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements included herein. In
addition, the following joint ventures also have debt that could become </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
financial statements reflect the following acquisitions, dispositions and changes in ownership subsequent to the occurrence of each transaction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
September&nbsp;30, 2000, Manhattan Village, a 551,847 square foot, regional shopping center, which was owned 10% by the Operating Partnership, was sold. The joint venture sold the property for
$89.0&nbsp;million,
including a note receivable from the buyer for $79.0&nbsp;million at a fixed interest rate of 8.75% payable monthly, until its maturity date of September&nbsp;30, 2001. On December&nbsp;28,
2001, the note receivable was paid down by $5.0&nbsp;million and the maturity date was extended to September&nbsp;30, 2002 at a new fixed interest rate of 9.50%. On July&nbsp;2, 2002, the note
receivable of $74.0&nbsp;million was paid off in full. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;14, 2001, Villa Marina Marketplace, a 448,262 square foot community shopping center located in Marina del Rey, California, a wholly-owned property of the Company, was sold. The
center was sold for approximately $99.0&nbsp;million, including the assumption of the existing mortgage of $58.0&nbsp;million, which resulted in a $24.7&nbsp;million gain. The Company used
approximately $26&nbsp;million of the net proceeds from this sale to retire $25.7&nbsp;million of its outstanding convertible subordinated debentures due December&nbsp;2002. The remaining
balance of the proceeds was used for general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
March&nbsp;19, 2002, the Company sold Boulder Plaza, a 159,238 square foot community center in Boulder, Colorado for $24.7&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used for general
corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;10, 2002, the Company acquired The Oaks, a 1.1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in Thousand Oaks, California. The total purchase price was $152.5&nbsp;million and was
funded with $108.0&nbsp;million of debt, bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.15%, placed concurrently with the acquisition. The balance </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=40,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=178249,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DO1132A.;46',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:16' -->
<A NAME="page_do1132_1_39"> </A>
<UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>of
the purchase price was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. The Oaks is referred to herein as the "2002 Acquisition Center." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
July&nbsp;26, 2002, the Operating Partnership acquired Westcor Realty Limited Partnership and its affiliated companies ("Westcor"). The total purchase price was approximately
$1.475&nbsp;billion including the assumption of $733&nbsp;million in existing debt and the issuance of approximately $72&nbsp;million of convertible preferred partnership units of the Operating
Partnership at a price of $36.55 per unit. Additionally, $18.9&nbsp;million of partnership units of Westcor Realty Limited Partnership were issued to limited partners of Westcor which, subject to
certain conditions, can be converted on a one for one basis into partnership units of the Operating Partnership. The balance of the purchase price was paid in cash which was provided primarily from
the $380.0 interim credit facility, which was subsequently paid in full in 2002 and a $250.0&nbsp;million term loan with a maturity of up to three years with two one-year extension
options and with an interest rate ranging from LIBOR plus 2.75% to LIBOR plus 3.00% depending on the Company's overall leverage level. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;8, 2002, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's interest in Panorama City Associates, which owns Panorama Mall in Panorama, California. The purchase price was
approximately $23.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;24, 2002, the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall in Ventura, California was sold for approximately $15.4&nbsp;million. The proceeds from the sale were used to repay
a portion of the term loan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;2, 2003, the Company sold its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway, a 296,153 square foot Phoenix area urban village, for approximately $29.4&nbsp;million. The proceeds from
the sale were used to repay a portion of the term loan. The sale resulted in a loss on sale of asset of $0.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's 50% interest in FlatIron Crossing. The purchase price consisted of approximately $68.3&nbsp;million in cash plus the
assumption of the joint venture partner's share of debt of $90.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
May&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company sold 49.9% of its partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera for a total purchase price of approximately $65.9&nbsp;million, which included the
assumption of a proportionate amount of the partnership debt in the amount of approximately $34.7&nbsp;million. The Company is retaining a 50.1% partnership interest and will continue leasing and
managing the asset. The sale resulted in a gain on sale of asset of $8.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
June&nbsp;6, 2003, the Shops at Gainey Village, a 138,000 square foot Phoenix area specialty center, was sold for $55.7&nbsp;million. The Company, which owned 50% of this property, received
total proceeds of $15.8&nbsp;million and recorded a gain on sale of asset of $2.8&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
August&nbsp;4, 2003, the Company sold Bristol Center, a 161,000 square foot community center in Santa Ana, California. The sales price was approximately $30.0&nbsp;million and the Company
recorded a gain on sale of asset of $22.2&nbsp;million which is reflected in discontinued operations. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=41,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=706621,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DO1132A.;46',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:16' -->
<A NAME="page_do1132_1_40"> </A>
<UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company acquired Northridge Mall, an 864,071 square foot super-regional mall in Salinas, California. The total purchase price was $128.5&nbsp;million and was funded
by sale proceeds from Bristol Center and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. Northridge Mall is referred herein as the "2003 Acquisition Center." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;18, 2003, the Company acquired Biltmore Fashion Park, a 610,477 square foot regional mall in Phoenix, Arizona. The total purchase price was $158.5&nbsp;million, which included the
assumption of $77.4&nbsp;million of debt. The Company also issued 705,636 partnership units of the Operating Partnership at a price of $42.80 per unit. The balance of the Company's 50% share of the
purchase price of $10.5&nbsp;million was funded by cash and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. The mall is owned in a 50/50 joint venture with an institutional partner. </FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A
portion of the Westcor portfolio is comprised of joint ventures and those properties are reflected using the equity method of accounting. The results of these acquisitions and the 2003 acquisition
of Biltmore Fashion Park are reflected in the consolidated results of operations of the Company in the income statement line item entitled "Equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures and the
management companies." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Many
of the variations in the results of operations, discussed below, occurred due to the Westcor portfolio and the 2002 and 2003 Acquisition Centers. For purposes of the 2003 financial results, the
term "Westcor portfolio" includes the Company's acquisition of the remaining 50% interest in FlatIron Crossing on January&nbsp;31, 2003. Crossroads Mall-Boulder, Parklane Mall and Queens
Center are currently under redevelopment and are referred to herein as the "Redevelopment Centers." All other Centers, excluding the Redevelopment Centers, the 2002 Acquisition Center, the Westcor
portfolio (which includes the two development properties), the 2003 Acquisition Center and Biltmore Fashion Park, are referred to herein as the "Same Centers," unless the context otherwise requires. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Revenues
include rents attributable to the accounting practice of straight-lining of rents which requires rent to be recognized each year in an amount equal to the average rent over the term of the
lease, including fixed rent increases over that period. The amount of straight-lined rents, included in consolidated revenues, recognized in 2003 was $2.9&nbsp;million compared to
$1.2&nbsp;million in 2002 and ($0.1) million in 2001. Additionally, the Company recognized through equity in income of unconsolidated joint ventures, $1.9&nbsp;million as its pro rata share of
straight-lined rents from joint ventures in 2003 compared to $2.3&nbsp;million in 2002 and $1.4&nbsp;million in 2001. These variances resulted from the Company structuring the majority of its new
leases using an annual multiple of CPI increases, which generally do not require straight-lining treatment and are offset by increases of $2.6&nbsp;million and $2.8&nbsp;million relating to the
2002 Acquisition Center, the acquisition of the Westcor portfolio and the 2003 Acquisition Center for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002, respectively. Currently, 29% of the mall and
freestanding leases contain provisions for CPI rent increases periodically throughout the term of the lease. The Company believes that using an annual multiple of CPI increases, rather than fixed
contractual rent increases, results in revenue recognition that more closely matches the cash revenue from each lease and will provide more consistent rent growth throughout the term of the leases. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company's historical growth in revenues, net income and Funds From Operations have been closely tied to the acquisition and redevelopment of shopping centers. Many factors, including the
availability and cost of </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=42,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=354149,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DO1132A.;46',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:16' -->
<A NAME="page_do1132_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>capital,
the Company's total amount of debt outstanding, interest rates and the availability of attractive acquisition targets, among others, will affect the Company's ability to acquire and redevelop
additional properties in the future. The Company may not be successful in pursuing acquisition opportunities and newly acquired properties may not perform as well as expected in terms of achieving the
anticipated financial and operating results. Increased competition for acquisitions may impact adversely the Company's ability to acquire additional properties on favorable terms. Expenses arising
from the Company's efforts to complete acquisitions, redevelop properties or increase its market penetration may have an adverse effect on its business, financial condition and results of operations.
In addition, the following describes some of the other significant factors that may impact the Company's future results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>General Factors Affecting the Centers; Competition:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Real property investments are subject to varying degrees of risk that may affect the
ability of the Centers to generate sufficient revenues to meet operating and other expenses, including debt service, lease payments, capital expenditures and tenant improvements, and to make
distributions to the Company and the Company's stockholders. Income from shopping center properties may be adversely affected by a number of factors, including: the national economic climate; the
regional and local economy (which may be adversely impacted by plant closings, industry slowdowns, union activities, adverse weather conditions, natural disasters, terrorist activities, and other
factors); local real estate conditions (such as an oversupply of, or a reduction in demand for, retail space or retail goods and the availability and creditworthiness of current and prospective
tenants); perceptions by retailers or shoppers of the safety, convenience and attractiveness of the shopping center; and increased costs of maintenance, insurance and operations (including real estate
taxes). A significant percentage of the Centers are located in California and the Westcor centers are concentrated in Arizona. To the extent that economic or other factors affect California or Arizona
(or their respective regions generally) more severely than other areas of the country, the negative impact on the Company's economic performance could be significant. There are numerous shopping
facilities that compete with the Centers in attracting tenants to lease space, and an increasing number of new retail formats and technologies other than retail shopping centers that compete with the
Centers for retail sales (see "Business-Competition"). Increased competition could adversely affect the Company's revenues. Income from shopping center properties and shopping center values are also
affected by such factors as applicable laws and regulations, including tax, environmental, safety and zoning laws (see "Business-Environmental Matters"), interest rate levels and the availability and
cost of financing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Dependence on Anchors/Tenants:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's revenues and funds available for distribution would be adversely affected if a significant
number of the Company's lessees were unable (due to poor operating results, bankruptcy, terrorist activities or other reasons) to meet their obligations, if the Company were unable to lease a
significant amount of space in the Centers on economically favorable terms, or if for any reason, the Company were unable to collect a significant amount of rental payments. A decision by an Anchor or
a significant tenant to cease operations at a Center could also have an adverse effect on the Company. In addition, mergers, acquisitions, consolidations, dispositions or bankruptcies in the retail
industry could result in the loss of Anchors or tenants at one or more Centers. (See "Business-Bankruptcy and/or Closure of Retail Stores.") Furthermore, if the store sales of retailers operating in
the Centers were to decline sufficiently, tenants might be unable to pay their minimum rents or expense recovery charges. In the event of a default by a lessee, the Center may also experience delays
and costs in enforcing its rights as lessor. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=43,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=893945,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DO1132A.;46',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:16' -->
<A NAME="page_do1132_1_42"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Real Estate Development Risks:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's business strategy has expanded to include the selective development and construction of retail
properties. Any development, redevelopment and construction activities that the Company undertakes will be subject to the risks of real estate development, including lack of financing, construction
delays, environmental requirements, budget overruns, sunk costs and lease-up. Furthermore, occupancy rates and rents at a newly completed property may not be sufficient to make the
property profitable. Real estate development activities are also subject to risks relating to the inability to obtain, or delays in obtaining, all necessary zoning, land-use, building,
occupancy and other required governmental permits and authorizations. If any of the above events occur, the ability to pay distributions and service the Company's indebtedness could be adversely
affected. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Joint Venture Centers:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company indirectly owns partial interests in 40 Joint Venture Centers as well as fee title to a site that is
ground leased to the entity that owns a Joint Venture Center and several development sites. The Company may also acquire partial interests in additional properties through joint venture arrangements.
Investments in Joint Venture Centers involve risks different from those of investments in wholly-owned Centers. The Company may have fiduciary responsibilities to its partners that could affect
decisions concerning the Joint Venture Centers. In certain cases, third parties share with the Company or have (with respect to one Joint Venture Center) control of major decisions relating to the
Joint Venture Centers, including decisions with respect to sales, financings and the timing and amount of additional capital contributions, as well as decisions that could have an adverse impact on
the Company's REIT status. In addition, some of the Company's outside partners control the day-to-day operations of seven Joint Venture Centers. The Company therefore does not
control cash distributions from these Centers and the lack of cash distributions from these Centers could jeopardize the Company's ability to maintain its qualification as a REIT. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Uninsured Losses:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each of the Centers has comprehensive liability, fire, terrorism extended coverage and rental loss insurance with insured
limits customarily carried for similar properties. The Company does not insure certain types of losses (such as losses from wars), because they are either uninsurable or not economically insurable. In
addition, while the Company or the relevant joint venture, as applicable, carries earthquake insurance on the Centers located in California, the policies are subject to a deductible equal to 5% of the
total insured value of each Center, a $100,000 per occurrence minimum and a combined annual aggregate loss limit of $200&nbsp;million on these Centers. Furthermore, the Company carries title
insurance on substantially all of the Centers for less than their full value. If an uninsured loss or a loss in excess of insured limits occurs, the Operating Partnership or the entity, as the case
may be, that owns the affected Center could lose its capital invested in the Center, as well as the anticipated future revenue from the Center, while remaining obligated for any mortgage indebtedness
or other financial obligations related to the Center. There is also no assurance that the Company will be able to maintain its current insurance coverage. An uninsured loss or loss in excess of
insured limits may negatively impact the Company's financial condition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>REIT Qualification:</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Qualification as a REIT involves the application of highly technical and complex Internal Revenue Code provisions for
which there are only limited judicial or administrative interpretations. The complexity of these provisions and of the applicable income tax regulations is greater in the case of a REIT such as the
Company that holds its assets in partnership form. The determination of various factual matters and circumstances not entirely within our control, including by the Company's partners in the Joint
Venture Centers, may affect its ability to qualify as a REIT. In addition, legislation, new regulations, administrative </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=44,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=288206,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DO1132A.;46',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:16' -->
<A NAME="page_do1132_1_43"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>interpretations
or court decisions could significantly change the tax laws with respect to the Company's qualification as a REIT or the federal income tax consequences of that qualification. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>If
in any taxable year the Company fails to qualify as a REIT, the Company will suffer the following negative results: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
Company will not be allowed a deduction for distributions to stockholders in computing its taxable income; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
Company will be subject to federal income tax on its taxable income at regular corporate rates. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
addition, the Company will be disqualified from treatment as a REIT for the four taxable years following the year during which the qualification was lost, unless the Company was entitled to relief
under statutory provisions. As a result, net income and the funds available for distribution to the Company's stockholders will be reduced for five years. It is also possible that future economic,
market, legal, tax or other considerations might cause the Board of Directors to revoke the Company's REIT election. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Assets and Liabilities  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Total assets increased to $4.1&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2003 compared to $3.7&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2002 and $2.3&nbsp;billion at
December&nbsp;31, 2001. During that same period, total liabilities were $1.6&nbsp;billion in 2001 and $2.4&nbsp;billion in 2002 and increased to $2.9&nbsp;billion in 2003. These changes were
primarily a result of the acquisitions and various debt and equity transactions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Developments  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>A. Acquisitions  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On January&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company purchased its joint venture partner's 50% interest in FlatIron Crossing. The purchase price consisted of approximately
$68.3&nbsp;million in cash plus the assumption of the joint venture partner's share of debt of $90.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
September&nbsp;15, 2003, the Company acquired Northridge Mall, an 864,071 square foot super-regional mall in Salinas, California. The total purchase price was $128.5&nbsp;million and was funded
by sale proceeds from Bristol Center (see "Dispositions") and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
December&nbsp;18, 2003, the Company acquired Biltmore Fashion Park, a 610,477 square foot regional mall in Phoenix, Arizona. The total purchase price was $158.5&nbsp;million, which included the
assumption of $77.4&nbsp;million of debt. The Company also issued 705,636 partnership units of the Operating Partnership at a price of $42.80 per unit. The balance of the Company's 50% share of the
purchase price of $10.5&nbsp;million was funded by cash
and borrowings under the Company's line of credit. Biltmore Fashion Park is owned in a 50/50 partnership with an institutional partner. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
January&nbsp;30, 2004, the Company, in a 50/50 joint venture with a private investment company, acquired Inland Center, a 1&nbsp;million square foot super-regional mall in San Bernardino,
California. The total purchase price was $63.3&nbsp;million and concurrently with the acquisition, the joint venture placed a $54&nbsp;million fixed rate </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>B. Financing Activitiy  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On May&nbsp;13, 2003, the Company issued $250&nbsp;million in unsecured notes maturing in May&nbsp;2007 with a one-year extension option bearing interest at
LIBOR plus 2.50%. The proceeds were used to pay down and create more availability under the Company's line of credit. In October&nbsp;2003, the Company entered into an interest rate swap agreement
which will effectively fix the interest rate at 4.45% from November&nbsp;2003 to October&nbsp;13, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
August&nbsp;7, 2003, the Company paid off the loan at Greeley Mall and placed a new $30.0&nbsp;million ten-year fixed rate loan on the property with an interest rate of 6.18%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In
September&nbsp;2003, the Company replaced floating rate loans at Chandler Festival and Chandler Gateway with new five year fixed rate loans of $32.0&nbsp;million and $20.0&nbsp;million,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On
November&nbsp;4, 2003, the Company closed on a $200&nbsp;million fixed rate ten-year loan on FlatIron Crossing bearing interest at 5.23%. Loan proceeds were used to pay off a
$180&nbsp;million floating rate loan secured by the property. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company has reached agreement on an $85.0&nbsp;million, five-year fixed rate loan with an interest rate of 4.63% on Northridge Mall. The rate on the loan is locked and this financing
is expected to close in April&nbsp;2004. Loan proceeds are expected to pay down the Company's unsecured floating rate debt. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>C. Redevelopment and Development Activity  </I></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>At Queens Center, the redevelopment and expansion continued. The project will increase the size of the center from 622,297 square feet to approximately 1&nbsp;million square
feet. Completion is planned in phases starting in 2004 with stabilization expected in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Lakewood Mall, Target opened a two-level Target store in the location formerly occupied by Montgomery Ward in October&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Redmond Town Center, Bon Marche opened a new department store in July&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Construction
continues at Scottsdale 101, a 420,824 square foot power center in north Phoenix and construction also continues at La Encantada, a 255,325 square foot specialty center in Tucson,
Arizona. Both of these projects are planned to open in phases through 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>At
Somersville Town Center in Antioch, California, a new 106,685 square foot Macy's store is under construction and is expected to open in the fall of 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Nordstrom
announced plans to open a 144,000 square foot store at The Oaks Mall in Thousand Oaks, California. This store opening is planned in conjunction with an expansion of the existing mall
tentatively scheduled to open in 2007. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A

<P><FONT SIZE=2>On

assumption of a proportionate amount of the partnership debt in the amount of approximately $34.7&nbsp;million. The Company is retaining a 50.1% partnership interest and will continue leasing and

June&nbsp;6, 2003, the Shops at Gainey Village, a 138,000 square foot Phoenix area specialty center, was sold for $55.7&nbsp;million. The Company, which owned 50% of this property, received

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents increased by 28.6% to $308.5&nbsp;million in 2003 from $239.9&nbsp;million in 2002. Approximately $60.1&nbsp;million of the increase relates
to the Westcor portfolio, $6.7&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the 2002 Acquisition Center, $4.2&nbsp;million relates to the Company acquiring 50% of its joint venture partner's interest
in Panorama and $2.9&nbsp;million relates to the 2003 Acquisition Center. Additionally, the Redevelopment Centers offset the increase in minimum and percentage rents by decreasing revenues by
$1.0&nbsp;million in 2003 compared to 2002 and a $5.3&nbsp;million offset related to the Company's sale of 49.9% of its partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>During
2001, the Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;141. (See "Statement on Critical Accounting Policies"). The amortization of below market leases, which is recorded in minimum rents, increased to $6.1
million in 2003 from $1.1 million in 2002. The increase is primarily due to a full year's amortization in 2003 from the acquistitions during 2002 compared to a partial year in 2002. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $159.8&nbsp;million in 2003 from $120.6 in 2002. Approximately $31.8&nbsp;million relates to the Westcor portfolio, $3.9&nbsp;million relates to the 2002
Acquisition Center, $4.7&nbsp;million relates to the Same Centers, $1.9&nbsp;million relates to Panorama Mall and $1.3&nbsp;million relates to the 2003 Acquisition Center. This is offset by a
$1.0&nbsp;million decrease relating to the Redevelopment Centers and a $2.3&nbsp;million decrease relating to the sale of 49.9% partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center and operating expenses increased to $171.7&nbsp;million in 2003 compared to $127.1&nbsp;million in 2002. The increase is a result of $42.9&nbsp;million
related to the Westcor Portfolio, the 2002 Acquisition </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=47,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=71443,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DQ1132A.;25',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1132_1_46"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Center
accounted for $3.1&nbsp;million of the increase in expenses, $1.6&nbsp;million relates to Panorama Mall, $1.4&nbsp;million relates to increased property taxes, recoverable expenses and
bad debt expense at the Redevelopment Centers and $3.1&nbsp;million represents increased property taxes, insurance and other recoverable and non-recoverable expenses at the Same
Centers. This is offset by a $2.0&nbsp;million decrease relating to the sale of 49.9% partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera and $5.5&nbsp;million relating to consolidating Macerich
Management Company effective July&nbsp;1, 2003, in accordance with FIN&nbsp;46. (See "New Pronouncements Issued"). Prior to July&nbsp;1, 2003, the Macerich Management Company was accounted for
using the equity method of accounting. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>REIT General and Administrative Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>REIT general and administrative expenses increased to $10.7&nbsp;million in 2003 from $7.4&nbsp;million in 2002, primarily due to increases in professional services, travel
expenses and stock-based compensation expense. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased to $108.7&nbsp;million in 2003 from $77.6&nbsp;million in 2002. Approximately $1.6&nbsp;million relates to additional capital
costs at the Same Centers, $2.0&nbsp;million relates to the 2002 Acquisition Center, $0.9&nbsp;million relating to the 2003 Acquisition Center, $1.3&nbsp;million relating to consolidating
Macerich Management Company effective July&nbsp;1, 2003, $0.4&nbsp;million relates to Panorama Mall and $16.8&nbsp;million relates to the Westcor portfolio. As a result of SFAS&nbsp;141, an
additional $9.5&nbsp;million of depreciation and amortization was recorded based on a reclassification of the purchase price of the 2002 and 2003 Acquisition Centers and the Westcor portfolio
between buildings and into the value of in-place leases, tenant improvements and lease commissions. This is offset by a $1.9&nbsp;million decrease relating to the sale of 49.9% of the
partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased to $132.5&nbsp;million in 2003 from $122.6&nbsp;million in 2002. Approximately $16.8&nbsp;million of the increase is related to the debt from
the Westcor portfolio, $0.5&nbsp;million from the 2002 Acquisition Center, $1.0&nbsp;million relates to the new $32.3&nbsp;million loan placed on Panorama Mall in January&nbsp;2003 and
$6.5&nbsp;million is related to the $250.0&nbsp;million of unsecured notes issued on May&nbsp;13, 2003. In addition, the interest expense relating to the debentures paid off in
December&nbsp;2002 reduced interest expense by $8.6&nbsp;million in 2003 compared to 2002 and the sale of 49.9% of the Company's partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera resulted in a
decrease of $3.4&nbsp;million compared to 2002. Capitalized interest was $12.1&nbsp;million in 2003, up from $7.8&nbsp;million in 2002 primarily due to the redevelopment and expansion of Queens
Center. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest represents the 20.3% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership by the Company during 2003. This compares to 24.7% not owned by the Company
during 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity in Income from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and Macerich Management Companies  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The income from unconsolidated joint ventures and the Macerich Management Companies was $58.9&nbsp;million for 2003, compared to income of $43.0&nbsp;million in 2002.
$5.6&nbsp;million was attributed to the acquisition of certain joint ventures in the Westcor portfolio and $0.5&nbsp;million relating to the sale of a 49.9% partnership interest in the Village at
Corte Madera. Additionally in 2002, a loss of $11.3&nbsp;million was </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=48,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=203390,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DQ1132A.;25',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1132_1_47"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>included
in unconsolidated joint ventures relating to the Company's investment in MerchantWired, LLC which included a $10.2&nbsp;million write down of assets. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain (Loss) on Sale of Assets  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A gain of $12.4&nbsp;million in 2003 represents $8.5&nbsp;million from the Company's sale of 49.9% of its partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera on
May&nbsp;15, 2003, $2.8&nbsp;million relates to the Company's sale of Gainey Village on June&nbsp;6, 2003 and $1.0&nbsp;million relates to gains on sales of peripheral land. This is compared
to a loss of $3.8&nbsp;million in 2002 representing primarily the write down of assets from the Company's various technology investments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Loss on Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2003, the Company recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $0.2&nbsp;million compared to $3.6&nbsp;million in 2002. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A gain of $22.0&nbsp;million in 2003 relates to the gain on sale of Bristol Mall on August&nbsp;4, 2003 of $22.2&nbsp;million and $0.2&nbsp;million relates to a loss on
the Company's sale of its 67% interest in Paradise Village Gateway on January&nbsp;2, 2003. This is compared to a gain of $26.1&nbsp;million in 2002 as a result of the Company selling Boulder
Plaza on March&nbsp;19, 2002 and recognizing a gain on sale of $13.9&nbsp;million and the Company
recognizing a gain of $12.2&nbsp;million as a result of the Company selling the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Income Available to Common Stockholders  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the purchase of the 2002 and 2003 Acquisition Centers, the Westcor portfolio, the Bristol, the Village at Corte Madera and Gainey Village sales, the
issuance of $420.3&nbsp;million of equity in November&nbsp;2002 which was used to pay off debt, and the foregoing results, net income available to common stockholders increased to
$113.2&nbsp;million in 2003 from $61.0&nbsp;million in 2002. In 2002, the sales of Boulder Plaza and the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall resulting in a total gain of
$26.1&nbsp;million and significantly increased net income available to common stockholders for the year ending December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $261.7&nbsp;million in 2003 compared to $206.2&nbsp;million in 2002. The increase is primarily due to the Westcor portfolio, the 2002 and 2003
Acquisition Centers and increased net operating income at the Centers as mentioned above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities was $383.8&nbsp;million in 2003 compared to cash used in investing activities of $918.3&nbsp;million in 2002. The change resulted
primarily from the acquisitions of the Westcor portfolio and 2002 and 2003 Acquisition Centers, the Company's purchase of its joint venture partner's 50% interest in FlatIron Crossing, the Company's
sale of 49.9% of its partnership interest in the Village at Corte Madera, an increase in equity of income of unconsolidated joint ventures due to the Westcor portfolio, the loss of
$10.2&nbsp;million in 2002 from the Company's investment in Merchant Wired, LLC and a $126.6&nbsp;million increase in development, redevelopment and expansion of Centers primarily due to the
Queens Center </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=49,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=522514,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DQ1132A.;25',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1132_1_48"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>expansion.
This is offset by $107.2&nbsp;million of proceeds received from the sale of Paradise Village Gateway, the Shops at Gainey Village, Bristol Center and the 49.9% interest in the Village at
Corte Madera and increased distributions from joint ventures primarily as a result of the Westcor portfolio. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow provided by financing activities was $115.7&nbsp;million in 2003 compared to cash flow provided by financing activities of $739.1&nbsp;million in 2002. The change
resulted primarily from the acquisitions of the Westcor portfolio in 2002 and the 2002 and 2003 Acquisition Centers, the construction loan at Queens Center of $101.3&nbsp;million, the new loan of
$32.2&nbsp;million at Panorama Mall and the $250.0&nbsp;million of unsecured notes issued on May&nbsp;13, 2003. This is offset by $471.9&nbsp;million of net proceeds from equity offerings in
2002 and a $108.0&nbsp;million loan placed on the 2002 Acquisition Center. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the acquisitions of the Westcor portfolio, the purchase of the 2002 and 2003 Acquisition Centers and the other factors mentioned above, Funds from
Operations&#151;Diluted increased 38.3% to $269.1&nbsp;million in 2003 from $194.6&nbsp;million in 2002. For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income available
to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenues  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Minimum and percentage rents increased by 14.7% to $240.0&nbsp;million in 2002 from $209.3&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $7.5&nbsp;million of the increase is
attributed to the Same Centers primarily due to releasing space at higher rents, $7.1&nbsp;million of the increase relates to the 2002 Acquisition Center, $0.7&nbsp;million relates to the Company
acquiring 50% of its joint venture partner's interest in Panorama and $28.3&nbsp;million relates to the Westcor portfolio. This is offset by a $9.9&nbsp;million decrease relating to the sale of
Villa Marina Marketplace in 2001 and a $1.8&nbsp;million decrease relating to the Redevelopment Centers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>During
2001, the Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;141. (See "Statement on Critical Accounting Policies"). This resulted in the Company recording $1.1 million of minimum rents related to the amortization
of below market leases in 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Tenant
recoveries increased to $120.6&nbsp;million in 2002 from $108.3&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $4.1&nbsp;million of the increase is attributable to the 2002 Acquisition Center,
$10.3&nbsp;million relates to the Westcor portfolio and $0.5&nbsp;million relates to the Same Centers. This is partially offset by $2.8&nbsp;million relating to decreases from the sale of Villa
Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Expenses  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Shopping center and operating expenses increased to $127.1&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to $109.5&nbsp;million in 2001. The increase is a result of $5.0&nbsp;million of
increased property taxes, insurance and other recoverable and non-recoverable expenses at the Same Centers. Additionally, effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, the Macerich Property Management
Company merged with and into Macerich Property Management Company, LLC ("MPMC, LLC"). Expenses for MPMC, LLC for periods commencing March&nbsp;29, 2001, were consolidated and represent
$1.2&nbsp;million of the change. Prior to March&nbsp;29, 2001, Macerich Property Management </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>48</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=50,EFW="2130493",CP="THE MACERICH COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=322899,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK035:[04BHL2.04BHL1132]DQ1132A.;25',USER='TOSBORNA',CD='12-MAR-2004;12:17' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1132_1_49"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Company
was an unconsolidated entity accounted for using the equity method of accounting. The 2002 Acquisition Center accounted for $4.2&nbsp;million of the increase in expenses,
$10.9&nbsp;million of the increase related to Westcor and $0.7&nbsp;million relates to the Redevelopment Centers. These increases are offset by decreases of approximately $2.9&nbsp;million
related to the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>REIT
general and administrative expenses increased to $7.4&nbsp;million in 2002 from $6.8&nbsp;million in 2001, primarily due to increases in professional services, travel expenses and
stock-based compensation expense. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation and Amortization  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Depreciation and amortization increased to $77.6&nbsp;million in 2002 from $65.0&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $3.6&nbsp;million relates to additional capital costs
at the Same Centers, $2.3&nbsp;million relates to the 2002
Acquisition Center and $7.6&nbsp;million relates to Westcor. This increase is offset by a decrease of $2.3&nbsp;million from the sale of Villa Marina Marketplace. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Interest Expense  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Interest expense increased to $122.6&nbsp;million in 2002 from $109.6&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $18.4&nbsp;million of the increase is related to the debt from
the Westcor transaction and $1.8&nbsp;million from the 2002 Acquisition Center. This increase is offset by decreases of approximately $4.0&nbsp;million related to the sale of Villa Marina
Marketplace and approximately $0.9&nbsp;million related to the payoff of debt in 2001. In addition, the interest expense relating to the debentures paid off in December&nbsp;2002 reduced interest
expense by $2.3&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to 2001. Capitalized interest was $7.8&nbsp;million in 2002, up from $5.7&nbsp;million in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Minority Interest  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The minority interest represents the 24.7% weighted average interest of the Operating Partnership that was not owned by the Company during 2002. This compares to 24.8% not
owned by the Company during 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity in Income from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and Macerich Management Companies  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The income from unconsolidated joint ventures and the Macerich Management Companies was $43.0&nbsp;million for 2002, compared to income of $32.9&nbsp;million in 2001.
Income from the Macerich Management Companies increased by $1.3&nbsp;million primarily due to MPMC, LLC being consolidated effective March&nbsp;29, 2001. SDG Macerich Properties, LP income
increased by $3.1&nbsp;million primarily due to lower interest expense on floating rate debt. Pacific Premier Retail Trust's income increased by $3.4&nbsp;million primarily due to a
$2.3&nbsp;million gain on sale of a portion of land at Redmond Town Center in 2002 and approximately $1.1&nbsp;million relating to increases in minimum and percentage rents. Additionally,
$10.1&nbsp;million was attributed to the acquisition of the Westcor portfolio which included $0.8&nbsp;million of revenue relating to SFAS&nbsp;141. These increases are offset by
$10.2&nbsp;million of loss from the write-down of the Company's investment in MerchantWired, LLC. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain (loss) on Sale or Write-Down of Assets  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>A loss of $3.8&nbsp;million in 2002 compares to a gain of $24.5&nbsp;million in 2001. Approximately $3.0&nbsp;million of the loss in 2002 represents the
write-down of assets from the Company's various technology investments </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Macerich Company&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<A NAME="page_dq1132_1_50"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>compared
to a gain on sale of assets of $24.5&nbsp;million in 2001 as a result of the Company selling Villa Marina Marketplace on December&nbsp;14, 2001. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Loss from Early Extinguishment of Debt  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>In 2002, the Company recorded a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $3.6&nbsp;million compared to a loss of $2.0&nbsp;million in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The 2002 gain of $26.1&nbsp;million was a result of the Company selling Boulder Plaza and recognizing a $13.9&nbsp;million gain on March&nbsp;19, 2002, and the Company
recognizing a gain of $12.2&nbsp;million as a result of the Company selling the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Income Available to Common Stockholders  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily as a result of the sales of Boulder Plaza and the former Montgomery Ward site at Pacific View Mall, the 2002 Acquisition Center, the Westcor transaction, the income
from Unconsolidated Joint Ventures and the foregoing results, net income available to common stockholders increased to $61.0&nbsp;million in 2002 from $58.0&nbsp;million in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow from operations was $206.2&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to $140.5&nbsp;million in 2001. The increase is primarily due to the Westcor transaction, the 2002
Acquisition Center, consolidating the results of MPMC, LLC effective March&nbsp;29, 2001, and increased net operating income at the Centers as mentioned above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash used in investing activities was $918.3&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to cash used in investing activities of $57.3&nbsp;million in 2001. The change resulted primarily
from the Westcor transaction, the 2002 Acquisition Center and the write-down of assets of $10.2&nbsp;million relating to MerchantWired, LLC, which is reflected in equity in income of
unconsolidated joint ventures. These decreases are offset by the net cash proceeds received of $15.3&nbsp;million in 2002 from the sales of Boulder Plaza and the former Montgomery Wards site at
Pacific View Mall. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Cash flow provided by financing activities was $739.1&nbsp;million in 2002 compared to cash flow used in financing activities of $93.0&nbsp;million in 2001. The change
resulted primarily from the new debt from the Westcor transaction, the $471.9&nbsp;million of net proceeds from the 2002 equity offerings, the financing of the 2002 Acquisition Center and the
refinancing of Centers in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Funds From Operations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Primarily because of the factors mentioned above, Funds from Operations&#151;Diluted increased 12.2% to $194.6&nbsp;million in 2002 from $173.4&nbsp;million in 2001.
For the reconciliation of FFO and FFO-diluted to net income available to common stockholders, see "Funds from Operations." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Macerich Company</I></FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_dq1132_1_51"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The Company intends to meet its short term liquidity requirements through cash generated from operations, working capital reserves, property secured borrowings and borrowing
under the new revolving line of credit. The Company anticipates that revenues will continue to provide necessary funds for its operating expenses and debt service requirements, and to pay dividends
to stockholders in accordance with REIT requirements. The Company anticipates that cash generated from operations, together with cash on hand, will be adequate to fund capital expenditures which will
not be reimbursed by tenants, other than non-recurring capital expenditures. The following table summarizes capital expenditures incurred at the Centers, including the pro rata share of
joint ventures, for the twelve months ending December&nbsp;31,: </FONT></P>
